results.title: Turning 18
results.creator_credit: Tony Wright, Penny Robins, Peter Kaufman, Open Channel Productions and Video Projects
results.brief_description: An amusing look at some serious issues that are related to turning eighteen - the age by which a person is legally recognised as an adult in this society. This program, subtitled, “Almost 20 Minutes” is a parody of the current affairs television program, “60 Minutes”.

results.title: The Floor is yours (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Richard Need, Management Training Ltd and Richard Need Productions
results.brief_description: A case study which tells the story of a young manager about to give his first business presentation and how he is saved from panic by help from an unexpected source. He discovers that good preparation is more than half the battle in successful communication and learns a tried and tested method that will see him through every kind of public speaking occasion.

results.brief_description: Examines research in the field of human attention with the focus on the apparent ability of some people to share their attention between two or more tasks at the same time.

results.title: Happy landing (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Clive Holloway, BBC-TV and Open University
results.brief_description: The program aims to show how the problems posed by ‘real world’ perceptual tasks (for example landing an aircraft) may lead to a different kind of perceptual theory than that normally generated by laboratory experiments. NB. Tape blank for first minute.

results.title: Tennis: the greats
results.creator_credit: Jack Egan, ABC-TV (Australia) and ABC Video
results.brief_description: From Suzanne Lenglen and Bill Tilden, the champions of the 1920s, to Margaret Court and Rod Laver at the end of the 1950s, this film shows the great players of the past in action. Film, privately owned by Adrian Quist, including travel with the Davis Cup teams enhances the story, which also discusses the inevitable rise of professional tennis. Narrated by Adrian Quist

results.title: Dionne quintuplets
results.creator_credit: Donald Brittain, Paul Wright, Peter Katadotis, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Back in 1934, Elzire Dionne delivered five identical girls. This documentary follows Cecile, Emilie, Marie, Yvonne and Annette through twenty one years of strange upbringing. When the girls were just infants, the premier of Ontario issued a court order removing them from their parent’s care. Cut off from the world and their family, over-publicised, viewed twice daily in a special viewing compound, they grew up as prize exhibits. Director Donald Brittain uses newsreel footage, home movie sequences and interviews to depict a historic event that became a tragic exploitation of a family.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Donald Brittain, Paul Wright, Peter Katadotis, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Emergency in Africa
results.brief_description: A documentary that looks at the emergency situation that exists in Africa. There is not enough food being produced to feed the people and a great proportion of the population, especially the children, suffer from disease and malnutrition. This film examines the type of relief that is being provided by the UNICEF organisation.

results.title: Understanding Cancer Pt.1
results.brief_description: This program is the first of a three part documentary that looks at cancer. Presented by Professor Richard Fox, from the Ludwig Institute for Cancer Research, this program examines issues such as, what is cancer? and what causes cancer? Cancer specialists discuss these issues and comment on the influences of factors such as diet, environment and genetics.
